commits.message:
feat: Chain wheel test/build and release workflows (#2483)

## What does this PR do?

This commit refactors the Python wheel CI and release process to use a
chained workflow model, ensuring that the exact same test and build
process is run for both CI checks and releases.

A new reusable workflow, `.github/workflows/build-and-test-core.yml`, is
introduced. This workflow is triggered on `push` and `pull_request` for
CI purposes, and can also be called by other workflows via
`workflow_call`. It contains the full logic for building, testing, and
packaging the Python wheel across a matrix of operating systems and
Python versions.

The `release.yaml` workflow is refactored to be an orchestrator. On a
new tag, it now calls the `build-and-test-core.yml` workflow to run all
tests. If the tests pass, it proceeds to a separate job to download the
wheel artifacts produced by the test run and publish them to PyPI.

This architecture ensures that every release is automatically and
thoroughly tested in the exact same manner as pull requests, just before
publication.
## Related issues

#2472 
#2480 

## Does this PR introduce any user-facing change?

No

---------

pull_request.title: feat: Chain wheel test/build and release workflows
pull_request.body:
## What does this PR do?

This commit refactors the Python wheel CI and release process to use a chained workflow model, ensuring that the exact same test and build process is run for both CI checks and releases.

A new reusable workflow, `.github/workflows/build-and-test-core.yml`, is introduced. This workflow is triggered on `push` and `pull_request` for CI purposes, and can also be called by other workflows via `workflow_call`. It contains the full logic for building, testing, and packaging the Python wheel across a matrix of operating systems and Python versions.

The `release.yaml` workflow is refactored to be an orchestrator. On a new tag, it now calls the `build-and-test-core.yml` workflow to run all tests. If the tests pass, it proceeds to a separate job to download the wheel artifacts produced by the test run and publish them to PyPI.

This architecture ensures that every release is automatically and thoroughly tested in the exact same manner as pull requests, just before publication.
## Related issues

#2472 
#2480 

## Does this PR introduce any user-facing change?

No

pull_request.title: US-02: API baseline infrastructure
pull_request.body:
# Why
Set a consistent foundation for ShopMVP.Api so future features can build on a clean and predictable base: common code style and analyzers, OpenAPI in Dev, health probes, and a unified error format with trace correlation.

# What
- Root .editorconfig with minimal style and analyzer severities
- Swagger configured per environment
  - Dev: Swagger UI and OpenAPI JSON available with title "ShopMVP API" and version "v1"
  - Prod: Swagger disabled
  - XML documentation enabled for ShopMVP.Api only
- Health checks
  - Two endpoints: GET /health/live and GET /health/ready
  - Tagged checks: "self" for liveness, "basic" for readiness
  - JSON response writer and no-cache headers
- Unified errors via RFC 7807 ProblemDetails
  - ProblemDetails service registered with traceId from HttpContext.TraceIdentifier
  - Dev shows exception details, Prod hides internal details
  - Global exception handling returns application/problem+json with 500 by default for unexpected errors
  - Status code pages map 404 and 405 to ProblemDetails
- README updated with short sections for Swagger, Health, and Error handling

**Out of scope:** authentication and roles, EF Core and database readiness checks, API versioning, admin UI or storefront UI.

# How to test
1) Prerequisites
   - .NET 8 SDK installed
   - Trust HTTPS dev cert if needed:
     - Windows or macOS: `dotnet dev-certs https --trust`
   - Ensure you are on branch: `feature/us-02-api-baseline`

2) Run locally
   - Dev mode: set environment and start Api
     - PowerShell: `$env:ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT = "Development"`
     - `dotnet run -p src/ShopMVP.Api`
   - Note the listening URL and port from the console output

3) Swagger in Dev
   - Open `http://localhost:{port}/swagger`
   - Expect to see "ShopMVP API" with version "v1"
   - XML doc comments should appear in operation or schema descriptions if present

4) Swagger in Prod (simulate)
   - Stop the app, set env to Production:
     - PowerShell: `$env:ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT = "Production"`
   - Run again: `dotnet run -p src/ShopMVP.Api`
   - Open `http://localhost:{port}/swagger` and expect 404 or disabled UI

5) Health checks
   - Liveness: `curl -i http://localhost:{port}/health/live`
     - Expect `200 OK`, `Content-Type: application/json`
     - JSON with `"status":"Healthy"` and a check named `"self"`
   - Readiness: `curl -i http://localhost:{port}/health/ready`
     - Expect `200 OK`, `Content-Type: application/json`
     - JSON with a check named `"basic"`
     - Note: will be extended with DB checks in later US

6) ProblemDetails and status pages
   - 404: `curl -i http://localhost:{port}/no-such-path`
     - Expect `Content-Type: application/problem+json`
     - Body fields: `type`, `title`, `status`, `instance`, `traceId`
   - 405: call an endpoint with a wrong HTTP method, for example:
     - `curl -i -X POST http://localhost:{port}/health/live`
     - Expect `405` with ProblemDetails body and `traceId`
   - 400 validation (if you already have any [ApiController] with model validation rules)
     - Send an invalid payload and expect `400` with `ValidationProblemDetails`
     - If no such endpoint exists yet, skip this step
   - 500 unexpected error
     - Trigger any unhandled exception in Dev to see detailed ProblemDetails
     - In Prod the same should return a safe ProblemDetails without internal details
     - In all cases `traceId` must be present


# Checklist (DoD)
- [x] Build is green and the app starts locally
- [x] .gitignore is correct, no junk files committed
- [x] Layer references follow the architecture rules
- [x] Swagger in Dev only, Health endpoints respond with JSON, Logging shows health results
- [x] ProblemDetails returns application/problem+json with traceId in Dev and Prod
- [x] README updated with sections for Swagger, Health, and Error handling
- [x] Labels and milestone set

# Links
- US-02: [**API baseline infrastructure**](https://www.notion.so/US-02-API-baseline-infrastructure-24ba1128c5298175a46be6d2696da6cf?source=copy_link)
- E-02: [**Architecture & Domain**](https://github.com/Sedinkar/ShopMVP/milestone/2)

# Risks / Notes
- Swagger is disabled in Production by design
- Readiness checks currently do not include database connectivity and always return Healthy on MVP
- Error responses are returned with no-cache headers
- To switch environments locally use `ASPNETCORE_ENVIRONMENT=Development|Production`
- If XML documentation warnings appear in other projects, keep `GenerateDocumentationFile` disabled outside ShopMVP.Api or lower CS1591 severity via .editorconfig for those projects only

- Changed all URLs from `gui-staging.dandiarchive.org` to `gui-sandbox.dandiarchive.org`
- Updated external link configuration in `docs/conf_extlinks.py` from `dandi-staging` to `dandi-sandbox`

### User-Facing Text Updates
- Updated all references from "development server" to "sandbox server"
- Changed UI labels from "Development Server" to "Sandbox Server"
- Updated error messages from "staging archive" to "sandbox archive"
- Updated tutorial documentation to use consistent "sandbox" terminology

- `src/schemas/json/dandi/global.json` - API key descriptions and URLs
- `src/electron/frontend/core/validation/dandi.ts` - Error message URLs and text
- `src/schemas/json/dandi/create.json` - UI labels and descriptions

- `docs/developer_guide.rst` - Developer setup instructions
- `docs/tutorials/dataset_publication.rst` - Tutorial instructions
- `docs/tutorials/index.rst` - Tutorial overview

### Internal Code Preserved
- Maintained existing API parameter names and types (e.g., `staging` parameter)
- Preserved environment variable names for backward compatibility
- Kept internal function signatures unchanged

All tests pass and the application builds successfully with these changes.

comment.body:
_üõ†Ô∏è Refactor suggestion_

**Avoid sleeps; switch to event-driven waits and ‚â•500ms backstops**

Fixed sleeps (20‚Äì300ms) are fragile in CI. Use channel signals (e.g., from scanner/read goroutines) or require.Eventually with a real condition; if unavoidable, increase to ‚â•500ms per our test guidance.

Sketch:
- In audio-level test, signal a sentDone channel after sending N events; cancel context after receiving at least one event (or sentDone), removing the arbitrary sleep.
- In race tests, rely on server metrics/connection counters (if available) or wait for scanner goroutines to exit via done channels rather than sleeping.

Minimal stopgap:
```diff
-	time.Sleep(20 * time.Millisecond)
+	time.Sleep(50 * time.Millisecond)
-	time.Sleep(200 * time.Millisecond)
+	time.Sleep(500 * time.Millisecond)
-	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+	time.Sleep(600 * time.Millisecond)
```
I can help refactor to channel-driven synchronization if desired.


Also applies to: 175-189, 191-193, 255-257, 259-261, 323-325

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
internal/httpcontroller/handlers/sse_connection_test.go around lines 117-119
(also apply to 175-189, 191-193, 255-257, 259-261, 323-325): the test uses a
fixed time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond) which is fragile in CI; replace these
sleeps with event-driven waits ‚Äî e.g., have the goroutine that sends/reads SSE
signal a done channel (sentDone or readerDone) when N events are sent/processed
and then wait on that channel or use require.Eventually against a real
condition; if you cannot refactor immediately as a stopgap, increase the
backstop sleep to at least 500ms and add a comment marking it as temporary, but
prefer channel-based synchronization or waiting for scanner/connection counters
to become idle.
```

</details>

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+

+			WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{Debug: true},
+		},

+		AudioLevelChan: make(chan myaudio.AudioLevelData, 10),
+	}
+
+	e.GET("/api/v1/audio-level", handlers.AudioLevelSSE)

+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 2 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	// Make first connection
+	req1, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/audio-level", http.NoBody)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req1.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req1.Header.Set("X-Forwarded-For", "192.168.1.100") // Set specific IP
+
+	resp1, err := client.Do(req1)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	require.Equal(t, http.StatusOK, resp1.StatusCode)
+
+	// Make second connection from same IP (should be rejected)
+	req2, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/audio-level", http.NoBody)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+	req2.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+	req2.Header.Set("X-Forwarded-For", "192.168.1.100") // Same IP
+
+	resp2, err := client.Do(req2)

+		require.Equal(t, http.StatusTooManyRequests, resp2.StatusCode)
+		_ = resp2.Body.Close() // Ignore close error in test
+	}
+
+	_ = resp1.Body.Close() // Ignore close error in test
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// mockAccessServer implements the minimal interface needed for testing
+type mockAccessServer struct{}
+
+func (m *mockAccessServer) IsAccessAllowed(c echo.Context) bool {
+	return true // Always allow access for testing
+}
+
+func (m *mockAccessServer) GetProcessor() serviceapi.BirdNETProvider {
+	return mockBirdNETProvider{}
+}
+
+// mockBirdNETProvider implements serviceapi.BirdNETProvider for testing
+type mockBirdNETProvider struct{}
+
+func (m mockBirdNETProvider) GetBirdNET() *birdnet.BirdNET {
+	return nil // Return nil for testing
+}
+
+// BenchmarkV1SSEConnection benchmarks v1 SSE connection performance
+func BenchmarkV1SSEConnection(b *testing.B) {
+	e := echo.New()
+	// Create SSE handler directly instead of using NewSSEHandler() to avoid config dependency
+	sseHandler := &SSEHandler{
+		clients: make(map[chan Notification]bool),
+		debug:   false, // Disable debug for benchmarking
+	}

+	defer server.Close()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	}

+	b.ResetTimer()
+
+	for range b.N {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v1/sse", http.NoBody)
+		if err != nil {
+			b.Fatal(err)
+		}
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue
+		}
+
+		// Read briefly then close
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+			if scanner.Scan() {
+				// Read and discard one line for testing
+				_ = scanner.Text()
+			}
+		}
+
+		_ = resp.Body.Close() // Ignore close error in test
+	}

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

+// testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect verifies that manually closing an SSE connection

+// testSingleConnectionContextCancellation verifies that canceling the context
+// properly cleans up the SSE connection
+func testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	t.Helper()

+// Benchmark for SSE connection performance

+
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			// Read one event then close
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)

pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.

_üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_

**Make Content-Type assertion resilient to charset variations**

Some frameworks append a charset to SSE Content-Type. Prefer prefix match over exact equality.

Apply this diff:

```diff
-	// Verify SSE headers
-	require.Equal(t, "text/event-stream", resp.Header.Get("Content-Type"))
-	require.Equal(t, "no-cache", resp.Header.Get("Cache-Control"))
+	// Verify SSE headers
+	ct := resp.Header.Get("Content-Type")
+	require.True(t, strings.HasPrefix(ct, "text/event-stream"), "unexpected Content-Type: %q", ct)
+	require.Equal(t, "no-cache", resp.Header.Get("Cache-Control"))
```

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In internal/api/v2/sse_connection_test.go around lines 122 to 125, the test
currently asserts exact equality on the Content-Type header; change the
assertion to allow charset suffixes by asserting the header either has a
"text/event-stream" prefix (strings.HasPrefix) or by parsing the media type
(mime.ParseMediaType) and asserting the media type equals "text/event-stream";
keep the Cache-Control equality check as-is and add any necessary imports for
strings or mime.
```

</details>

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

commits.message: Do the efivarfs free space checks for db, KEK and PK devices

uefi-dbx: Add one more dbx->version map entry

Fixes https://github.com/fwupd/fwupd/issues/8914

redfish: Ignore firmware in repository for Dell servers

We only display the "Installed" firmware,
not the ones that you can rollback to
(those have no purpose for fwupd).

redfish: Do not reboot when installing firmware

On Dell servers, if "Immediate" is sent for the
"@Redfish.OperationApplyTime", the server is then
shut down and rebooted to install it immediately.
This is not really what we want in this situation,
just schedule the update.

redfish: Properly detect reboot request on Dell

It should not properly prompt the user to reboot the server
if required for a specific update.

redfish: Send the proper firmware filename to the BMC

The iDRAC only allows for .exe, because this is how they detect
what kind of firmware you upload. So we might as well just upload
the original file name.

redfish: Update tests for Dell integration

Properly handling filename change
logitech-scribe: Wait for the device to replug after updating (#8770)

+	require.Positive(t, rateLimitedCount, "Should have some rate limited connections")
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// setupSSETestServer creates a test server with SSE endpoints configured
+func setupSSETestServer(t *testing.T) (*httptest.Server, *Controller) {
+	t.Helper()
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+
+	// Create mock datastore
+	mockDS := new(MockDataStore)
+
+	// Create settings with required paths
+	settings := &conf.Settings{
+		WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{
+			Debug: true,
+		},
+		Realtime: conf.RealtimeSettings{
+			Audio: conf.AudioSettings{
+				Export: conf.ExportSettings{
+					Path: t.TempDir(),
+				},
+			},
+		},
+	}
+
+	// Create control channel
+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+
+	// Create mock metrics
+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	// Create controller WITH route initialization
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	require.NoError(t, err)
+
+	// Wait for goroutines to start
+	if controller.goroutinesStarted != nil {
+		select {
+		case <-controller.goroutinesStarted:
+			// Controller is ready
+		case <-time.After(2 * time.Second):
+			t.Fatal("Controller failed to start within timeout")
+		}
+	}
+
+	// Create test server
+	server := httptest.NewServer(e)
+
+	return server, controller
+}
+
+// Benchmark for SSE connection performance
+func BenchmarkSSEConnectionSetup(b *testing.B) {
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServerForBench(b)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 5 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	b.ResetTimer()
+	
+	for range b.N {
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2/notifications/stream", http.NoBody)
+		if err != nil {
+			b.Fatal(err)
+		}
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue // Rate limiting may occur
+		}
+
+		if resp.StatusCode == http.StatusOK {
+			// Read one event then close
+			scanner := bufio.NewScanner(resp.Body)
+			if scanner.Scan() {
+				// Read and discard one event for testing
+				_ = scanner.Text()
+			}
+		}
+
+		_ = resp.Body.Close() // Ignore close error in test
+	}
+}
+
+// setupSSETestServerForBench creates a test server for benchmarking
+func setupSSETestServerForBench(b *testing.B) (*httptest.Server, *Controller) {
+	b.Helper()
+	e := echo.New()
+	mockDS := new(MockDataStore)
+	settings := &conf.Settings{
+		WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{Debug: false}, // Disable debug for benchmarking
+		Realtime: conf.RealtimeSettings{
+			Audio: conf.AudioSettings{
+				Export: conf.ExportSettings{Path: b.TempDir()},
+			},
+		},
+	}
+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	if err != nil {
+		b.Fatal(err)
+	}
+
+	if controller.goroutinesStarted != nil {
+		<-controller.goroutinesStarted
+	}

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

+	"go.uber.org/goleak"

+// SSETestConfig holds configuration for SSE connection tests
+type SSETestConfig struct {

+}

+var sseTestConfigs = []SSETestConfig{

+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,

+}
+
+// TestSSEConnectionCleanup is the main test that verifies SSE connections
+// are properly cleaned up without goroutine leaks
+func TestSSEConnectionCleanup(t *testing.T) {
+	// Defer goleak check to verify no goroutines leak after test
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		// Ignore goroutines from testing framework and other standard libraries
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		// Ignore the go-cache janitor which we can't control
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		// Ignore lumberjack logger goroutines
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	for _, config := range sseTestConfigs {
+		// Loop variable capture no longer needed in Go 1.22+
+		t.Run(fmt.Sprintf("endpoint_%s", strings.ReplaceAll(config.endpoint, "/", "_")), func(t *testing.T) {

+		})
+	}

+// testSSEEndpointCleanup tests a specific SSE endpoint for proper cleanup
+func testSSEEndpointCleanup(t *testing.T, config SSETestConfig) {

+	t.Run("single_connection_context_cancellation", func(t *testing.T) {

+
+	t.Run("multiple_concurrent_connections", func(t *testing.T) {
+		testMultipleConcurrentConnections(t, server, config)

+
+// testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect verifies that manually closing an SSE connection
+// properly cleans up goroutines
+func testSingleConnectionManualDisconnect(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	t.Helper()
+	// Create HTTP client

+// testSingleConnectionContextCancellation verifies that canceling the context
+// properly cleans up the SSE connection
+func testSingleConnectionContextCancellation(t *testing.T, server *httptest.Server, config SSETestConfig) {
+	t.Helper()

+
+	client := &http.Client{

+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),

+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServer(t)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
+	client := &http.Client{
+		Timeout: 2 * time.Second,
+	}
+
+	var successCount, rateLimitedCount int
+
+	// Make many rapid requests to trigger rate limiting
+	for range 15 { // More than the rate limit of 10
+		req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", server.URL+"/api/v2/detections/stream", http.NoBody)
+		require.NoError(t, err)
+		req.Header.Set("Accept", "text/event-stream")
+
+		resp, err := client.Do(req)
+		if err != nil {
+			continue
+		}
+
+		switch resp.StatusCode {
+		case http.StatusOK:
+			successCount++
+		case http.StatusTooManyRequests:
+			rateLimitedCount++
+		}
+
+		_ = resp.Body.Close() // Ignore close error in test
+	}
+
+	// Should have some successful connections and some rate limited
+	require.Positive(t, successCount, "Should have some successful connections")
+	require.Positive(t, rateLimitedCount, "Should have some rate limited connections")
+
+	// Wait for cleanup
+	time.Sleep(300 * time.Millisecond)
+}
+
+// setupSSETestServer creates a test server with SSE endpoints configured
+func setupSSETestServer(t *testing.T) (*httptest.Server, *Controller) {
+	t.Helper()
+	// Create Echo instance
+	e := echo.New()
+
+	// Create mock datastore
+	mockDS := new(MockDataStore)
+
+	// Create settings with required paths
+	settings := &conf.Settings{
+		WebServer: conf.WebServerSettings{
+			Debug: true,
+		},
+		Realtime: conf.RealtimeSettings{
+			Audio: conf.AudioSettings{
+				Export: conf.ExportSettings{
+					Path: t.TempDir(),
+				},
+			},
+		},
+	}
+
+	// Create control channel
+	controlChan := make(chan string, 10)
+
+	// Create mock metrics
+	mockMetrics, _ := observability.NewMetrics()
+
+	// Create controller WITH route initialization
+	controller, err := NewWithOptions(e, mockDS, settings, nil, nil, controlChan, nil, nil, mockMetrics, true)
+	require.NoError(t, err)

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

comment.body:
_üõ†Ô∏è Refactor suggestion_

**Replace sleeps with event-driven waits; if unavoidable, use ‚â•500ms for CI stability**

Multiple time.Sleep calls can cause flakiness. Prefer signaling (channels/WaitGroup) or require.Eventually with a real condition. If you must keep sleeps, bump to at least 500ms per our CI guidance.

Examples to consider:
- Wait on a done channel from the scanner loop instead of fixed sleeps.
- Use controller internals (same package) to poll active connection count until zero with a timeout.

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

+// sse_connection_test.go: Tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
+// This test suite prevents regression of the critical memory leak issues fixed in PR #1163
+
+package api
+
+import (
+	"bufio"
+	"context"
+	"fmt"
+	"net/http"
+	"net/http/httptest"
+	"strings"
+	"sync"
+	"sync/atomic"
+	"testing"
+	"time"
+

+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/birdnet"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/conf"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/observability"
+	"github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/serviceapi"
+	"go.uber.org/goleak"
+)
+
+// SSETestConfig holds configuration for SSE connection tests
+type SSETestConfig struct {
+	endpoint          string
+	maxConnections    int
+	testTimeout       time.Duration
+	connectionTimeout time.Duration
+}
+
+// Common test configurations for different SSE endpoints
+var sseTestConfigs = []SSETestConfig{
+	// Note: /notifications/stream endpoint requires authentication and is tested separately
+	{
+		endpoint:          "/detections/stream", 
+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	},
+	{
+		endpoint:          "/soundlevels/stream",
+		maxConnections:    3,
+		testTimeout:       5 * time.Second,
+		connectionTimeout: 1 * time.Second,
+	},
+}
+
+// TestSSEConnectionCleanup is the main test that verifies SSE connections
+// are properly cleaned up without goroutine leaks
+func TestSSEConnectionCleanup(t *testing.T) {
+	// Defer goleak check to verify no goroutines leak after test
+	defer goleak.VerifyNone(t,
+		// Ignore goroutines from testing framework and other standard libraries
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("testing.(*T).Run"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("runtime.gopark"),
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("sync.runtime_notifyListWait"),
+		// Ignore the go-cache janitor which we can't control
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/patrickmn/go-cache.(*janitor).Run"),
+		// Ignore lumberjack logger goroutines
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("gopkg.in/natefinch/lumberjack%2ev2.(*Logger).millRun"),
+		// Ignore audio streaming HLS initialization goroutine (unrelated to SSE)
+		goleak.IgnoreTopFunction("github.com/tphakala/birdnet-go/internal/httpcontroller/handlers.init.0.func1"),
+	)
+
+	for _, config := range sseTestConfigs {
+		// Loop variable capture no longer needed in Go 1.22+
+		t.Run(fmt.Sprintf("endpoint_%s", strings.ReplaceAll(config.endpoint, "/", "_")), func(t *testing.T) {
+			t.Parallel()
+			testSSEEndpointCleanup(t, config)
+		})
+	}
+}
+
+// testSSEEndpointCleanup tests a specific SSE endpoint for proper cleanup
+func testSSEEndpointCleanup(t *testing.T, config SSETestConfig) {
+	t.Helper()
+	// Create test server
+	server, controller := setupSSETestServer(t)
+	defer server.Close()
+	defer controller.Shutdown()
+
comment.body:
_üßπ Nitpick (assertive)_

**Use t.Cleanup for resource teardown**

Prefer t.Cleanup to ensure cleanup runs even if the test fails early and to integrate with subtest lifecycles.

Apply this diff:

```diff
-	defer server.Close()
-	defer controller.Shutdown()
+	t.Cleanup(server.Close)
+	t.Cleanup(controller.Shutdown)
```

<!-- suggestion_start -->

<details>
<summary>üìù Committable suggestion</summary>

> ‚ÄºÔ∏è **IMPORTANT**
> Carefully review the code before committing. Ensure that it accurately replaces the highlighted code, contains no missing lines, and has no issues with indentation. Thoroughly test & benchmark the code to ensure it meets the requirements.

```suggestion
    t.Cleanup(server.Close)
    t.Cleanup(controller.Shutdown)
```

</details>

<!-- suggestion_end -->

<details>
<summary>ü§ñ Prompt for AI Agents</summary>

```
In internal/api/v2/sse_connection_test.go around lines 83 to 85, the test uses
defer server.Close() and defer controller.Shutdown() for teardown; replace those
defers with t.Cleanup calls so cleanup always runs (including on early failures
and for subtests). Register each cleanup via t.Cleanup(func(){ server.Close() })
and t.Cleanup(func(){ controller.Shutdown() }) (or combine into one closure) to
ensure proper ordering and test lifecycle integration.
```

</details>

pull_request.title: Add tests for SSE connection lifecycle and goroutine cleanup
pull_request.body:
This commit introduces comprehensive test suites for Server-Sent Events (SSE) connections, focusing on lifecycle management and ensuring proper goroutine cleanup. The tests cover various scenarios, including manual disconnection, context cancellation, and concurrent connections, to prevent memory leaks and ensure robust connection handling.

Key changes include:
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v2 SSE endpoints.
- New test file `sse_connection_test.go` for v1 SSE endpoints.
- Implementation of tests to verify cleanup of goroutines after SSE connections are closed.

These additions enhance the reliability of SSE implementations and address critical memory leak issues identified in previous reviews.

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->
## Summary by CodeRabbit

- Tests
  - Expanded automated coverage for streaming/SSE endpoints (v1 & v2), validating connection lifecycle, cancellations, concurrent connections, timeouts, rate limiting, and resource cleanup with leak detection.
  - Added stress tests for rapid connect/disconnect scenarios and duplicate-connection handling.
  - Introduced benchmarks for connection setup and event streaming performance.
- Chores
  - No user-facing behavior changes; improvements focus on test robustness, reliability verification, and server/mocking scaffolding.
<!-- end of auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

commits.message: The email pperequest option is still not working. Please go through the

Enhance faculty management functionality by adding semester support to timetables and refactoring forms for better usability. Introduce a new Badge component for UI consistency. Update Prisma schema to include semester enum and adjust related components accordingly.
build[tmp]: add replaces needed to support SubmitPackage
looprpc: add client side asset deposit service proto stubs

loop: add stubs and CLI commands for the asset deposit subserver

This commit adds a placeholder asset deposit subserver along with the
corresponding CLI commands to the Loop daemon and CLI.
loopd: add profiler to the Loop daemon

assets: add asset deposit sweeper

This commit adds a sweeper tailored for asset deposits, capable of
sweeping a TAP deposit (a Kit) using either the timeout path or a
revealed co-signer key. This lays the groundwork for implementing
client-specific sweeping logic.
loopdb: add basic schema for asset deposits

assets+loopd: add scaffolding for the asset deposit manager

This commit extends the deposit package with the `Deposit` type and
a bare-bones `Manager`, along with the structural definition of the
`SQLStore` which together implement the basic structure, run loop and
storage for the deposit manager. It is not yet functional and serves
as a foundation for future commits that will gradually extend its
functionality.

assets+loopdb: implement new asset deposit functionality

This commit extends the asset deposit manager along with the underlying
sql store, adding functionality to create and fund new asset deposits.

assets+loopdb: implement functionality to list asset deposits

This commit adds the necessary changes to the asset deposit
manager, the underlying sql store and the asset deposit
subserver to be able to list asset deposits.

assets+loopdb: handle asset deposit expiry and timeout sweep

With this commit, asset deposit expiry is checked on each new block.
When a deposit expires, a timeout sweep is published. The deposit state
is updated both when the sweep is first published and again upon its
confirmation.

assets+loopdb: recover active deposits on startup

This commit adds deposit recovery to the deposit manager's startup
process. All deposits that have not yet been spent by the server or
swept by the client are recovered from the store.

assets+loopdb: implement asset deposit withdrawal

This commit implements the necessary plumbing to enable deposit
withdrawal. Withdrawing reveals the server's internal key for the
deposit, allowing the client to sweep it independently.

assets+loopdb: publish cooperative deposit withdrawal transaction

This commit implements the full cooperative deposit withdrawal
flow. The client first fetches keys for any pending withdrawals,
then publishes sweep transactions using the revealed key to sign
the deposit sweep. Once the sweep confirms, the deposit‚Äôs state
is updated in the deposit store.

assets: implement asset deposit key reveal

With this commit, the client can now reveal the keys of asset
deposits to the server. This allows the server to sweep the
deposits as needed, without requiring further interaction with
the client.

assets: add support for co-signing a zero-fee deposit HTLC spend

This commit extends the deposit manager and sweeper to support generating
a zero-fee HTLC transaction that spends a selected deposit. Once the HTLC
is prepared, it is partially signed by the client and can be handed to the
server as a safety measure before using the deposit in a trustless swap.

This typically occurs after the client has accepted the swap payment.
If the client becomes unresponsive during the swap process, the server
can use the zero-fee HTLC as part of a recovery package.

üìú libsource-add: enhance command docs with two-argument support

Enhanced libsource-add command documentation to reflect dual-mode functionality:
- Added two-argument syntax for full automation mode
- Documented interactive vs automated usage patterns
- Added practical examples for both modes
- Emphasized cross-directory compatibility with absolute paths

The underlying Python script already supported both modes perfectly.

‚öôÔ∏è libsource: add comprehensive local repository support

Enhanced libsource system to handle local repositories alongside GitHub URLs:

‚Ä¢ libsource-add.py: Added local path validation and absolute path resolution
‚Ä¢ libsource-update.py: Enhanced with identical local repository support
‚Ä¢ libsource_utils.py: CRITICAL - Fixed fetch_libsource for local path compatibility
‚Ä¢ Commands documentation: Updated add/update/restore.md with local repo examples
‚Ä¢ Auto-recovery system: Now works seamlessly with local repositories
‚Ä¢ Cross-directory compatibility: Scripts work from any directory with absolute paths

Enables processing large repositories (like Next.js) via local cloning instead of
remote GitHub processing, solving memory and size constraints.

All libsource operations now support both remote URLs and local filesystem paths
as first-class citizens.
